title: Big Purchase Decisions
description: Explore how you approach major financial decisions together.

questions.text: Before a big purchase, I need to...
choices: Research extensively and compare options
Talk it through and get a gut feeling
Sleep on it for a while
Know we can afford it comfortably

therapeutic.rationale: Decision-making processes vary—some need data, others need discussion, others need time, others need certainty. Knowing your partner's process helps you support rather than rush or frustrate them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The researcher may feel the gut-feeler is impulsive; the gut-feeler may feel the researcher is overthinking. Both are trying to make a good decision—just differently.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared decision processes make big purchases smoother. You'll naturally move at the same pace.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Think of a big purchase you're proud of. What made you feel ready to decide?

questions.text: When it comes to 'how much is too much,' I tend to...
choices: Have a firm number in mind and stick to it
Be flexible if something is really worth it
Focus on value, not just price
Feel uncomfortable spending a lot regardless

therapeutic.rationale: Spending thresholds reveal risk tolerance and values. Some are firm on budgets; others flex for quality; some focus on ROI; some are uncomfortable with big spending period. These orientations shape every major purchase.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The firm-number person may feel the flexible person is careless; the flexible person may feel the firm-number person is rigid. Understand what drives each approach.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared spending thresholds prevent a common conflict. You'll naturally agree on what's reasonable.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's the most you've ever spent on one thing? How did you feel about it afterward?

questions.text: I feel best about a big purchase when...
choices: We both genuinely agree it's the right call
We've done our homework and feel informed
It aligns with our bigger goals
It feels exciting, not just practical

therapeutic.rationale: What makes a purchase feel 'right' varies—agreement, information, alignment, or excitement. Knowing your partner's satisfaction criteria helps you make decisions that feel good to both.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The agreement-seeker may not feel settled without explicit buy-in; the excitement-seeker may feel the practical partner is killing the joy. Both needs are valid.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared satisfaction criteria mean you'll both feel good about purchases for the same reasons.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When has a purchase felt really right? What made it feel that way?

questions.text: If we disagreed about a big purchase, I'd want us to...
choices: Keep talking until we find common ground
Hear each other out, then compromise
Let whoever cares more have the final say
Wait until we're both truly ready

therapeutic.rationale: Disagreement navigation predicts how you'll handle financial conflict. The keep-talking approach values consensus; compromise values efficiency; defer-to-one values passion; waiting values readiness.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different approaches can frustrate in the moment. The consensus-seeker may feel the compromiser gives up too easily; the waiter may feel the talker is pressuring. Name your style ahead of time.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared disagreement approach means you'll navigate conflict the same way. Know your style's strengths and blind spots.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you usually handle it when you and your partner want different things? What works?

questions.text: The role of big purchases in our life together should be...
choices: Carefully planned milestones
Flexible based on opportunities that arise
Balanced between practical and fun
Minimal—experiences matter more than things

therapeutic.rationale: How you view big purchases reveals life values—milestone-markers plan ahead; opportunists stay flexible; balancers want both; minimalists prioritize differently. Alignment here shapes major life decisions.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different views on big purchases can create friction over houses, cars, vacations. The milestone-planner may clash with the opportunist; the minimalist may clash with both. Talk about the 'why' behind your view.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared views make planning easier. You'll naturally agree on what role big purchases play in your life.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What big purchases matter most to you? What would you happily skip? Why?
